text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.

Early in the Cold War, US military radar scanning 
for Soviet bombers detected that something had

entered North American airspace. The US and 
Canada started prepping for action...although

we don’t exactly know what action since all these 
files are confidential. But we do know that before

any really drastic measures were taken, military 
intelligence discovered that what they assumed

was a Soviet bomber was actually a flock of Canada 
geese. And this wasn’t just a fluke flock of fowl;

since radar debuted in 1935, people using the 
technology to identify incoming aircraft and

bad weather have regularly been fooled by 
birds. But we've since gotten really good

at erasing birds from radar - which 
has, weirdly, ended up helping birds.

That Soviet-spotting radar, like all 
radar, would send out radio waves and

then “listen” for what bounced back off 
stuff in the sky. But it was only equipped

to tell us that something was up there - it 
couldn't tell us anything about that thing.

Today, we’ve improved radar technology to provide 
us with way more info, and we have computers

capable of analyzing that data in real-time to 
give us a much clearer idea of what’s there. For

example, we upgraded radar to detect shifts in 
wave frequencies, which gave us the ability to

measure the speed of objects we were picking up in 
the sky - just like the radar that police use to

catch speeders. This made it easy to distinguish 
birds from planes that fly hundreds of km/h. And

to improve weather forecasting, we switched from 
single-polarization radars to dual-polarization

radars, which transmit both horizontally and 
vertically-oriented waves at once. This gives

us more data to evaluate the consistency in 
size and shape of a mass of things in the sky.

A mass of nearly identically-sized 
and shaped things, like rain or snow,

will return horizontally and vertically-aligned 
waves that are very similar in size and closely

aligned with each other. But the less uniform 
things are, like hail or even more so, a flock

of birds flapping their wings, the more the 
returned waves differ from each other. Computer

algorithms can then filter out anything that's not 
uniform enough to be weather and get rid of it.

But one scientist’s trash is another scientist’s 
treasure. Bird researchers realized they could

use publicly available weather radar but filter 
it in reverse to get unprecedented information

on birds. For years, conservationists 
couldn’t figure out where hundreds of

thousands of threatened Canadian swallows were 
spending their time in-between breeding seasons.

Even in perfectly clear skies, they can’t 
easily track swallows across the country...and

it’s hard to preserve a species’ habitat 
if you don’t know where that habitat is.

But with new-fangled radar and filtering 
techniques, conservationists can track the

swallows along much of their migratory journey 
even through fowl weather and multiple rest

stops. All they have to do is look for the 
beautiful, concentric blooms swallows create

every time they leave their roosts, and 
continue to follow their radar signature.

So, thanks to modern radar, tracking swallows 
is no longer a wild goose - or swallow - chase.

This video’s sponsor, Nature Canada, has used 
these same radar techniques to identify potential

roosting sites for threatened swallows around 
the lower Great Lakes in Ontario. Pinpointing the

sites can still be difficult but where good radar 
data is available, Nature Canada's scientists and

community partners can much more quickly start 
the fieldwork of confirming the roosting sites,

counting the swallow species there, and 
determining the best ways to protect them.

Nature Canada has been helping to save 
birds and other wildlife for over 80

years through conservation, education, and 
policy. To give nature a fighting chance,

Nature Canada says we need to protect at least 30 
percent of the world's lands and ocean by the year

2030. To find out how you can help achieve 30x30, 
visit naturecanada.ca. Thanks, Nature Canada!
